item.title: Ordering asynchronous updates with coroutines, part 2: Restart with hand-off
item.description: Another serialization pattern for coroutines is where calling some method initiates some asynchronous activity, and if the method gets called again while the activity is still incomplete, you want to let the previous activity run to completion, and then run it again.

item.title: The Crypto-Carry Trade
item.description: This is not a crypto bull or bear case piece. It’s simply a discussion of some crypto-currency policy problems which must be addressed over the next few years. The way the US monetary system reacts to these problems or fails to will have huge consequences. The author is ex-faculty at a hedge fund and does math for a living, all opinions are his own, but facts are cited.

item.title: Hundreds of Economists: Marijuana Prohibition Costs Billions, Legalization Would Earn Billions

item.title: My phone case, the hidden state of an RNN
item.description: What I needed was a new phone case. But I wanted a case that declares “my owner is a nerdy deep learning engineer”. So I made a visualisation of an RNN and had it printed, and I’m quite happy with it. This post is the origin story of this case, or, how to mash together a book, a deep learning library, some free computer time and a layout algorithm to get a pretty bunch of pixels.
item.author: (Douglas Orr)

item.title: Saving a restic backup the hard way
item.description: This is the end of the holidays in which I spent a long time building a backup infrastructure like a responsible adult. The villain of the following story is the junk MIPS machine which held hostage most of my important data (about 1TB). Its evil plan was to build up a corrupted backup snapshot for a whole week and have me deal with it. Various options were available to me, but I decided to use the scalpel and manually strike at the core.

item.title: A meditation on three dead side projects
item.description: If you're building a side project your motivation likely fits in the overlap of two broad categories: education (and, in general, practicing the joy of your craft) and money (clout, fame, etc). The story of these three dead projects is ultimately the story of how (not) to balance these motivations
item.author: (Kenny Bergquist I'm a software engineer in DC.)
